Mongolia: Vegetable Production and Irrigated

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on proposed loans to 
Mongolia for the Vegetable Production and Irrigated Agriculture Project. The report also describes 
the proposed administration of a grant to be provided by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction 
(JFPR) for the Supporting Irrigation Scheme in Central Mongolia Project, and if the Board 
approves the proposed loans, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, approve 
the administration of the grant. 
 
2.  The  project  will  support  the modernization  of  government-owned  irrigation  networks 
serving about 7,000 hectares (ha) of land. The project will promote income and employment 
generation in rural areas where poverty is endemic. This will be achieved by diversification from 
traditional low-value grain crops into high-value vegetables. It will also build farmers’ capacity for 
climate-smart production and better water and irrigation management. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  Mongolia’s economy has been characterized by rapid growth and transformation since 
transitioning from central planning in the early 1990s. Mineral exports were the main driver for 
achieving middle-income status in 2011. However, Mongolia’s vulnerability to external shocks 
underscored the need for a more diversified and labor-intensive economic structure for the rural 
population. In 2018, agriculture’s share in employment was 26.7% while it contributed only 10.8% 
of Mongolia’s gross domestic product.1 In line with the government’s focus to accelerate economic 
diversification and job creation, agriculture has become a priority for growth.2 It is the main source 
of livelihood in rural areas, where more than one-third of the total population lives.3 Poverty in rural 
areas (30.8% in 2018) remains higher than in urban areas (27.2% in 2018).4 Limited income-
generation opportunities and lack of resilience to natural disasters increase the risk of rural–urban 
migration. Agriculture is not sufficiently diversified and relies heavily on imports for vegetables and 
fodder, which in turn threatens national food security and the disaster risk resilience of the livestock 
industry. Only about half of the country’s vegetable demand was met by domestic production in 
2008‒2016. Vegetables are in high demand by more health-conscious citizens, and a more 
balanced diet can be expected to have considerable public health benefits. 
 
4.  Inefficient and climate-vulnerable irrigation services. More frequent droughts induced 
by climate change are a threat to food security, and particularly to vegetable production, which 
requires reliable access to irrigation services.5 In 2017, only 1% of Mongolia’s land area (777,000 ha) 
was cultivated, of which only 1.1% (8,900 ha) was used for vegetables (mainly beets, cabbages, 
carrots, cucumbers, garlic, onions, tomatoes, and turnips). The country’s irrigation systems are 
recognized as having low water productivity and lacking resilience to severe droughts and floods, 
although sufficient water resources are available—only 1.6% of the internal renewable water 
resources were withdrawn in 2014.6 The climate is trending toward a higher annual average 
 
1  ADB. 2018. Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2018. Manila. 
2  ADB. 2017. Country Partnership Strategy: Mongolia, 2017–2020—Sustaining Inclusive Growth in a Period of 
Economic Difficulty. Manila. 
3  National Statistics Office of Mongolia. 2019. Mongolian Statistical Yearbook 2018. Ulaanbaatar. 
4  World Bank. 2019. Mongolia’s 2018 Poverty Rate. 
5  Ministry of Environment and Tourism. 2018. Mongolia’s Third National Communication of Mongolia under the United 
Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, pp.190. https://unfccc.int/process-and-meetings. 
6  ADB. 2017. Country Water Security Assessment. Consultant’s final report. Manila (TA 8855-MON).

2 
temperature and less annual average rainfall, leading to a decline in river runoff. Existing irrigation 
infrastructure, and fodder and vegetable yields are threatened by water shortages in early spring, 
snowmelt river floods throughout spring, and flash floods from storms. 
 
5.  Environmentally unsustainable production systems. After the collapse of the former 
Soviet Union, the cropped area declined from its peak of 837,868 ha in 1989 to 162,040 ha in 
2006, as government support through national and regional crop research and extension centers 
declined. The cultivation techniques are unsustainable in terms of water productivity and the use 
of agrochemical inputs with unknown levels of residue in marketed crops. The productivity of 
vegetable-growing systems is further limited by a lack of access to seeds of high-yielding, climate-
resilient varieties. The absence of reliable quality assurance testing of inputs such as pesticides 
increases production costs and poses the potential risk of environmental pollution. The lack of 
agrochemical residue-testing capacity at government agencies threatens food safety and access 
to premium-price marketing opportunities. 
 
6.  Inadequate technical and institutional management capacity. Small farm sizes with 
inadequate access to efficient and climate-resilient irrigation limit the scope for productivity and quality-
enhancing  mechanization.  Individual  small-scale  farmers  lack  access  to  improved  production 
technologies, which require larger-scale operations to be profitable. About 300 cooperatives and 
35,000 households in the country grow vegetables on plots of up to 100 ha, but the total sown area 
was only 8,904 ha in 2018.3 Cooperative and farmer incomes are low and opportunities curtailed. In 
the  absence  of  post-harvest  and  storage  facilities,  and  with  low  awareness  of  value-added 
opportunities and marketing, farmers sell their vegetables mainly to middlemen. 
 
7.  Government policy. Backed by its Sustainable Development Vision 2030, Government 
Action Plan, 2016–2020, and State Policy on Food and Agriculture and Crop Production Law, 
Mongolia is committed to improve vegetable production.7 The state policy stresses the need to 
strengthen agricultural productivity and production management through a value chain approach, 
adaptation to climate change, and capacity building for farmers. The government targets for local 
vegetable production to meet 70% of domestic demand by 2020, and 100% by 2025, through 
support for initiatives such as on-farm mechanization, climate-resilient greenhouses, and water-
saving  irrigation  technology.  Policies  prioritizing  smallholder  farming  offer  an  enabling 
environment for meeting these targets. Following on from Mongolia’s National Programme for 
Food Security (2009–2016),8 the government intends to enhance water productivity and expand 
the country’s irrigated land from 54,000 ha in 2019 to 120,000 ha by 2030. 
 
8.  Strategic fit. The project is in line with Strategy 2030 of the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) by creating knowledge and promoting rural development and food security.9 Supporting a 
diversified agriculture sector with inclusive economic growth is a key strategic priority for ADB in 
its country partnership strategy for Mongolia, 2017–2020.10 The project will help improve the water 
productivity and climate resilience of irrigation systems, expand vegetable production and value 
chain links, and institutionalize residue testing for food safety, which is consistent with the four 
 
7  Sustainable Development Vision 2030 aims to increase irrigated land by adopting new and efficient irrigation 
technologies on 65,000 ha by 2020 (100,000 ha by 2025, 120,000 ha by 2030); boost farmland fertility; and curb soil 
degradation. 
8  Government of Mongolia. 2009. National Programme for Food Security (2009−2016). Ulaanbaatar. 
9  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. Manila. 
10 ADB. 2017. Country Partnership Strategy: Mongolia 2017–2020—Sustaining Inclusive Growth in a Period of 
Economic Difficulty. Manila.

3 
priority areas of ADB’s Operational Plan for Agriculture and Natural Resources and ADB’s Water 
Operational Plan 2011–2020.11 
 
9.  Lessons. The project design incorporates lessons from previous and ongoing projects 
financed by ADB and others in Mongolia, as well as from project preparation.12 Accordingly, the 
project responds to the need to (i) support government executing and implementing agencies in 
developing their project implementation capacity; (ii) expand the capacity of design institutes to 
identify and apply modern water-efficient irrigation methods in subproject designs; (iii) enable the 
careful  design  of  water-efficient  irrigation  systems  that  support  climate-smart  agricultural 
production;  (iv)  promote  sound  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  of  upgraded  systems, 
particularly through community grower groups (CGGs), to ensure their long-term sustainability; 
and  (v)  help  set  up  CGGs  and  introduce  them  to  climate-smart  production  technologies, 
particularly for vegetables. 
 
B.  Project Description 
 
10.  The project is aligned with the following impact: income generation and enterprise support 
for smallholder vegetable farmers increased.13 The project will have the following outcome: 
efficiency of climate-resilient agricultural production and marketing increased.14 
 
11.  Output 1: Efficient and climate-resilient irrigation infrastructure and management 
systems installed. The project team will focus on (i) upgrading, modernizing, and climate-
proofing irrigation and drainage infrastructure;15 (ii) strengthening coordination and management 
of irrigation services, irrigated land, and irrigation infrastructure, including storage ponds to build 
resilience  against  prolonged  droughts,  to  ensure  efficient,  reliable,  and  equitable  irrigation 
supplies for agricultural land; and (iii) planting trees for shelter belts around the modernized 
irrigated areas. The team will upgrade, modernize, and climate-proof 12 selected schemes along 
with directly associated infrastructure to provide irrigation services for 7,000 ha.16 The project will 
finance the remodeling and improvement of main, secondary, and tertiary canals or pipes, 
drainage facilities, field application systems, such as high-efficiency center pivot sprinkler systems 
and drip irrigation for 240 ha, and associated structures; and, where needed, construction of new 
access roads and windbreaks. Soum (district) governments will be strengthened to conduct O&M 
of irrigation systems and will pilot a modern asset management system. The project will create 
240 jobs during construction, of which 40% are earmarked for women and 10% for households 
headed by women; and ensure that all contracts for the 3,094 households to be involved in the 
farming of new vegetable plots will be co-signed by women. 
 
12.  Output 2: Environmentally sustainable agricultural production systems improved. 
The project aims to improve food safety, environmental sustainability, and climate resilience of 
agricultural  production  systems,  focusing  specifically  on  agrochemical  residue  testing  and 
supporting the implementation of a new law on plant seeds by promoting the introduction of new 
high-yielding and climate-resilient vegetable seed varieties. The project will support the national 
 
11 ADB. 2015. Operational Plan for Agriculture and Natural Resources: Promoting Sustainable Food Security in Asia 
and the Pacific in 2015–2020. Manila; and ADB. 2011. Water Operational Plan, 2011–2020. Manila. 
12 ADB. 2017. Community Vegetable Farming for Livelihood Improvement. Manila (financed by JFPR); ADB. 2012. 
Technical Assistance to Mongolia for the Establishment of Climate-Resilient Rural Livelihoods. Manila (financed by 
JFPR). 
13 Government of Mongolia. 2016. Mongolia Sustainable Development Vision 2030. Ulaanbaatar. 
14 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
15 Climate-proof irrigation systems increase the seasonal availability of crop water and are resilient against severe 
weather events such as storms and floods, and are well operated with efficient water allocation and monitoring. 
16 Project Administration Manual (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

4 
Institute for Plant Protection (IPP) with testing equipment and reagents to boost its testing 
capacity; IPP will be able to handle an additional 4,000 tests to ensure the safety of imported 
pesticides and to monitor the residues in food products. This is expected to reduce the use of 
harmful agrochemicals and to build consumer trust in domestically produced vegetables. The 
project team will coordinate with the national extension center to support four regional crop 
research institutes (CRIs) by (i) providing equipment and facilities such as climate-controlled 
growth chambers, storage cool rooms, sheds, fencing, mechanization packages, seed cleaning 
and packaging equipment, conservation farming equipment, and teaching facilities; (ii) conducting 
small-scale irrigation rehabilitation and modernization; and (iii) providing greenhouses and low-
carbon solutions to extend the cropping seasons and achieve high-value vegetable and quality 
seedling production. This is expected to increase the production capacity for vegetable seeds by 
0.65 tons and for seed potatoes by 10 tons.17 A total of 20 women researchers and 192 women 
from CGGs will be given technical support and training on best practices. 
 
13.  Output  3:  Technical,  institutional,  and  management  capacity  and  coordination 
strengthened. The project team will set up 48 CGGs in the 12 irrigation schemes, which target 
women for 40% of the membership and 25% of leadership positions; and provide training on 
improved vegetable production for 480 CGG participating farmers, including 40% women, in 
collaboration with the CRIs. The two main providers of extension services to vegetable farmers 
will be crop research centers such as the Institute of Plant and Agriculture Science, and a 
facilitation partner such as a local nongovernment organization. Project-supported CRIs will 
provide capacity building on good agricultural practice and integrated pest management for 
farmers’ improved management of natural resources with less use of agrochemicals, more use of 
climate-smart agriculture practices, and better vegetable production, processing and marketing 
techniques. To further strengthen CGGs, the project will provide mechanization technology 
packages, all-weather greenhouses with solar-powered heating and long-life films, and small cool 
rooms for product storage. The equipment will be provided through a combination of ADB loan 
and JFPR grant to the soum governments, which can then make it available to the CGGs based 
on predetermined eligibility criteria.18 
 
C.  Value Added by ADB 
 
14.  Innovations. The project design contains innovative features such as (i) adoption of high-
efficiency irrigation technology in cold regions; (ii) greater food safety and less environmental 
pollution by building the residue-testing capacity of the IPP; (iii) summer and winter greenhouses, 
including  low-carbon  options  for  water-efficient  production  of  high-value  crops  and  longer 
cropping seasons; (iv) promotion of a plan to allocate land within the upgraded irrigation schemes 
to poor and disadvantaged households and train them in the production of high-value crops, 
including vegetables; and (v) integration of an easy-to-use asset management system with 
remote-sensing technology that helps diagnose irrigation performance and resolve problems in a 
timely manner. Stronger resilience to climate change is achieved by (i) replacing open distribution 
canals with buried pipes to significantly reduce maintenance costs and water loss; (ii) adopting 
modern center pivot and lateral move sprinklers that can be programmed for efficient irrigation; 
and (iii) introducing greenhouses that contribute to a more circular use of inputs, including water. 
 
 
17 This will build on achievements of other interventions for drought-resilient seeds, such as those funded by 
International Maize and Wheat Improvement Center and the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation. 
18 The criteria for determining eligibility are that (i) a CGG is in place with effective government and management 
arrangements, and (ii) a plan is agreed by all members as to how farmers in the group will have equitable access to 
machinery and facilities.

5 
15.  Knowledge sharing. ADB published project preparation lessons and market opportunities 
in a technical report which identified opportunities for ADB financed public sector interventions to 
enhance smallholder participation in vegetable value chains.19 The project’s innovative climate-
smart  agriculture  concept  with  a  focus  on  water  productivity  offers  a  unique  opportunity  to 
demonstrate value-added modern agriculture practices to other developing member countries. The 
project’s experience with the remote-sensing system for monitoring the modernized irrigation 
schemes will be documented and disseminated through regional technical assistance to further 
develop remote-sensing tools for diagnosis, investments, repairs, and the management of irrigation 
schemes in other developing member countries.20 
 
D.  Summary Cost Estimates and Financing Plan 
 
16.  The project is estimated to cost $46.25 million (Table 1). Detailed cost estimates by 
expenditure category and by financier are provided in the project administration manual (PAM) 
(footnote 16).

Source: Asian Development Bank estimates. 
 
17.  The government requested a regular loan of $14.7 million from ADB’s ordinary capital 
resources to help finance the project. The loan will have a 25-year term, including a grace period 
of 6 years; an annual interest rate determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered 
rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility, a commitment charge of 0.15% per year; and such other 
terms and conditions set forth in the draft loan and project agreements. Based on the straight-line 
repayment method, the average maturity is 15.25 years, and the maturity premium payable to 
ADB is 0.1% per year. The government also requested a concessional loan of $25.3 million from 
ADB’s ordinary capital resources to help finance the project. The loan will have a 25-year term, 
including a grace period of 5 years; and an annual interest rate of 2% per year. The JFPR will

Productivity Measurement in Irrigation Project. Manila.

6 
provide grant cofinancing equivalent to $2 million, to be administered by ADB.21 The grant will 
finance activities under outputs 1 and 3. 
 
18.  The summary financing plan is in Table 2. ADB will finance the expenditures in relation to 
civil works, goods, and consulting services totaling 86.5% of the total project costs through a 
regular loan (31.8%) and a concessional loan (54.7%).

19.  Food security investments are estimated to cost $46.25 million, comprising the JFPR grant of 
$2.0 million, counterpart contribution of $4.25 million, and loans totaling $40.0 million from ADB’s 
ordinary capital resources. Investments in climate-resilient irrigation and agricultural production 
systems will catalyze agribusiness development in the food processing industry. Investments in 
national and regional agricultural extension centers will build the capacity of technicians and farmers 
for using climate-smart production systems and integrated pest management. 
 
20.  Climate mitigation is estimated to cost $7.1 million, and climate adaptation is estimated to 
cost $22.2 million. ADB and ADB-administered funds will finance 100% of mitigation and 100% 
of adaptation costs. Details are in the PAM.

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
22.  The project feasibility study considered alternatives and identified the most suitable after 
consideration  of  the  anticipated  climate  change  impacts,  irrigation  scheme  performance, 
environmental impacts, cost, resource use effectiveness, and O&M requirements. Key adaptation 
measures include using reliable and efficient water control, distribution, and application practices; 
low-impact headworks; diversification into climate-resilient crops; and adoption of climate-smart 
cultivation practices. Greenhouse gas emission savings are achieved by minimizing the need for 
power  to  distribute  water  and  operate  equipment.  Climate  resilience  measures  include 
incorporating  infrastructure  practices  against  frost  damage;  reducing  water  use;  providing 
protection measures against runoff and wind erosion; introducing cropping and tillage practices 
to minimize soil disturbance; extending cropping seasons; and gradually improving overall ground 
cover and the organic matter content of soil. Environmental sustainability will be enhanced by 
reducing the use of agrochemicals through integrated pest management, stabilizing water source 
access, protecting land and soil from erosion, and reducing annual river channel disturbances. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial Viability 
 
23.  The economic analysis indicated that the overall project is economically viable, with an 
economic internal rate of return of 20.2% and an economic net present value of MNT112.0 billion. The 
analysis also confirmed the economic viability of the 12 irrigation subprojects. Sensitivity analysis 
indicated that the project is robust against the negative scenarios examined, such as an increase in 
investment costs, a reduction in benefits, and an increase in O&M costs. The financial analysis included 
(i) a fiscal sustainability analysis to assess the capacity of the final borrower, the Government of 
Mongolia, to provide sufficient funds for all incremental recurrent costs incurred by the project;22 and    
(ii) an analysis of the financial statements of the CRIs and IPP. 
 
 
 
 
22 While the soum governments will be responsible for financing and implementing the O&M of headworks and main 
canals, their financial capacity is limited, and they are expected to have to rely on financing from the central 
government.

8 
C.  Sustainability 
 
24.  The sustainability of the outcomes and outputs will be maintained over the economic life of 
the project by a combination of ensuring proper O&M of the equipment provided for the irrigation 
schemes and establishing the CGGs in a sustainable manner. Proper O&M will be achieved by 
formulating procurement activities to achieve the standardization of irrigation equipment across the 
subprojects, inclusion in the equipment contracts of the requirement to provide training and manuals 
on O&M to project consultants, soum officials, and key subproject participants, as well as other 
persons involved. The Government will be responsible for O&M of irrigation infrastructure and the 
project will support the Government with drafting a policy for irrigation service payments. The 
sustainability of the CGGs will be promoted by their formalization, capacity building by the facilitation 
team,  diversification  of  production,  and  promotion  of  processing  to  increase  crop  incomes. 
Mitigation measures relating to the project’s institutional, environmental, social, economic, and 
financial risks were incorporated into project implementation to minimize the medium- and long-
term effects on natural resources, pollution, biodiversity, and financial and economic factors.23 
 
D.  Governance 
 
25.  The pre-mitigation financial management risk of the executing and implementing agencies, 
Ministry  of  Food,  Agriculture,  and  Light  Industry  (MOFALI),  including  the  Crop  Production 
Development Policy Coordination Department, is moderate because of (i) weak internal auditing 
functions, and (ii) insufficient numbers of accounting and financial management staff in MOFALI. 
These weaknesses will be mitigated by the inclusion of a financial management specialist in the 
project implementation unit (PIU). 
 
26.  MOFALI has only one staff member who is directly in charge of procurement. MOFALI 
staff are already loaded with government duties and their numbers are not sufficient. Therefore, 
the PIU will include experienced procurement staff to help support  the implementation. The 
procurement risk assessment confirmed that MOFALI has sufficient experience in project and 
procurement management of ADB-funded projects, and with this support will be able to fully comply 
with  the  ADB  Procurement  Policy  (2017,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and  Procurement 
Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, as amended from time to time). Value for money will be 
achieved by using the lowest evaluated cost option together with appropriate qualification and 
technical requirements as main evaluation criteria for the procurement of goods and works; and 
by using scoring systems with an emphasis on quality in the case of consulting services. 
 
27.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the government and MOFALI. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures 
are described in the PAM. 
 
E.  Poverty, Social, and Gender 
 
28.  Poverty and social. The project offers opportunities for inclusive development and 
poverty reduction by enhancing the productivity of vegetable production through stable water 
supply, training, and provision of technology packages, leading to income generation for farmers. 
Local  people,  including  poor  households,  are  expected  to  benefit  from  socioeconomic 
opportunities during the project’s implementation and operation. A total of 3,548 households 
(12,261 individuals), including 1,041 poor households (3,599 individuals), are expected to benefit 
from the project. This includes 454 households that currently farm vegetable on old land plots in 
 
23 Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

9 
the project irrigation areas and 3,094 households that will be involved in vegetable farming on 
new land plots. The project will create about 240 local jobs during construction. It will also provide 
training to farming households to strengthen vegetable value chains. 
 
29.  The project team prepared a social development action plan (SDAP) based on the poverty 
and social analysis. The SDAP comprises necessary actions and indicators under each output to 
ensure benefits for smallholder farmers, including the poor. The SDAP also includes measures to 
mitigate social risks. Consultations were undertaken with stakeholders during project preparation 
and will continue during project implementation. A consultation and participation plan for the 
project implementation stage is included in the PAM. 
 
30.  Gender.  The  project  is  classified  effective  gender  mainstreaming,  following  ADB’s 
Guidelines for Gender Mainstreaming Categories of ADB Projects.24 Women are involved in 
vegetable production and processing (vegetable pickling, jams, and jellies), but on a small scale, 
i.e., for domestic consumption and local sales. Women’s participation in farmers groups, decision 
making,  and  post-harvest  commercial  value  chains  needs  improvement.  The  project  will 
strengthen women’s capacity for and participation in the entire vegetable value chain activities; 
and they are expected to significantly benefit from the project. The project team prepared a gender 
action plan (GAP) based on the gender analysis to ensure that the project contributes to improved 
gender equality. The GAP targets that (i) 100% of documents for the engagement of households 
in vegetable production, including allocation of new land plots, are co-signed by women; (ii) 40% 
of  jobs  during  construction  are  for  women;  (iii)  30%–50%  of  participants  in  consultation, 
awareness-raising, and training activities are women; (iv) women account for 40% of members 
and 25% of leadership positions in the CGGs; (v) 50% of farmers receiving improved seeds and 
technology packages are women; and (vi) women are given specific training on vegetable 
processing and marketing techniques. Key gender targets are also included in the design and 
monitoring framework. 
 
31.  Capacity  for  implementation  and  monitoring  of  plans.  MOFALI  has  experience  in 
implementing ADB projects, including an ongoing ADB-administered and JFPR financed vegetable 
production project (footnote 12). The PIU under MOFALI will implement and monitor the GAP and 
SDAP. To implement social and gender measures properly, (i) the PIU will include a social and gender 
specialist; and (ii) MOFALI and project soums will appoint social and gender focal points for 
implementing, monitoring, and reporting on the social and gender measures listed in the SDAP and 
the GAP. 
 
F.  Safeguards 
 
32.  In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the project’s safeguard 
categories are as follows. 25 
 
33.  Environment  (category  B).  The  project  team  prepared  an  initial  environmental 
examination report, including an environmental management plan, in accordance with ADB’s 
Safeguard Policy Statement.26 An environment safeguard specialist will be included in the PIU 
and  will  coordinate  the  implementation  of  the  environmental  management  plan.  A  project 
grievance redress mechanism is also in place. 
 
 
24 ADB. 2012. Guidelines for Gender Mainstreaming Categories of ADB Project. Manila. 
25 ADB. Safeguard Categories. 
26 ADB. 2013. Safeguard Policy Statement. Operations Manual. OM F1. Manila. Available both in English and 
Mongolian language.

10 
34.  The project will contribute to environmental benefits through the introduction of water-
efficient irrigation infrastructure and management practices, and the promotion of organic fertilizer 
and integrated pest management. Environmental risks arise from (i) potentially unsustainable 
levels of water extraction; (ii) construction of large rock barriers and weirs to channel water for 
irrigation—these may affect flow regimes and, for three subprojects, will be the first water 
infrastructure  to  be  introduced  on  otherwise  natural  rivers;  (iii)  potential  expanded  use  of 
agricultural chemicals; and (iv) ecological impacts of one subproject located within an important 
biodiversity area. The project accounts for these risks to the extent possible through (i) hydrological 
modeling, which confirms that all source rivers have adequate water supply to meet irrigation 
needs and comply with national environmental flow requirements; (ii) procedures for measuring, 
reporting, and enforcing water allocation and environmental flow volumes; (iii) weir designs to 
retain natural free-flowing rivers; (iv) training for improved agricultural practices; and (v) ecological 
surveys to clarify sites’ ecological values and ensure that impacts on biodiversity are avoided. 
 
35.  Involuntary resettlement (category C). The project is not expected to have involuntary 
resettlement impacts. All civil works will be implemented on state-owned land and will not involve 
acquisition of nonstate land, physical or economic displacement, or restriction on land use. No 
legacy issues were found in any of the irrigation schemes. In Nogoon Khashaa (Uliastai soum) 
eight households and one company hold land possession or ownership rights along the existing 
main canal that will be covered and lined within the existing rights of way without permanent land 
acquisition and resettlement impacts. The households and the company were consulted during 
project  preparation  regarding  potential  temporary  impacts  on  gardens  and  fences  during 
construction,  and  they  support  the  canal’s  upgrade.  Any  structures  that  may  be  impacted 
temporarily during construction will be compensated for a replacement cost or will be reinstated 
by contractors under the project. ADB prepared a resettlement framework to address temporary 
impacts during construction and any unanticipated impacts during project implementation. The 
resettlement framework is included in the PAM. The ADB loan will provide consultant support to 
help MOFALI follow the resettlement framework during the project implementation. 
 
36.  Indigenous peoples (category C). The project is not expected to have any impacts on 
distinct and vulnerable communities of ethnic minorities that would trigger the requirements of 
ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement on indigenous people. 
 
G.  Summary of Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan 
 
37.  Significant risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 4 and described in 
detail in the risk assessment and risk management plan (footnote 23). 
 
Table 4: Summary of Risks and Mitigating Measures 
Risks  Mitigation Measures 
Government fiscal resources become insufficient to  Full and timely provision of counterpart funds for 
continue support for counterpart funds, debt  operation and maintenance of the project-
servicing, and/or operation and maintenance of the  funded facilities is included in the project loan 
project-funded infrastructure.  covenants. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
IV.  ASSURANCES 
 
38.  The government and MOFALI have assured ADB that implementation of the project shall 
conform to all applicable ADB requirements, including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, financial management, and disbursement

11 
as described in detail in the PAM and loan documents. The government and MOFALI have agreed 
with ADB on certain covenants for the project, which are set forth in the draft loan agreements. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
39.  I am satisfied that the proposed loans would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve: 
 
(i)  the loan of $14,700,000 to Mongolia for the Vegetable Production and Irrigated 
Agriculture Project, from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, in regular terms, with 
interest to be determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate 
(LIBOR)-based lending facility; for a term of 25 years, including a grace period of 
6 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with 
those set forth in the draft loan agreement presented to the Board; and  
 
(ii)  the loan of $25,300,000 to Mongolia for the Vegetable Production and Irrigated 
Agriculture Project, from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, in concessional terms, 
with an interest charge at the rate of 2% per year during the grace period and 2% 
per year thereafter; for a term of 25 years, including a grace period of 5 years; and 
such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set 
forth in the draft loan agreement presented to the Board. 
 
 
 
Masatsugu Asakawa 
President 
 
5 February 2020

Key Activities with Milestones 
1. Efficient and climate-resilient irrigation infrastructure and management systems installed 
1.1  Upgrade irrigation infrastructure (Q3 2020–Q3 2025). 
1.2  Conduct training and capacity-building activities for farmers and local government on joint reservoir 
operations management (Q3 2022). 
1.3  CGGs to plant windbreaks (Q2 2023). 
1.4  Procure drip/precision irrigation equipment to vulnerable households (Q2 2023). 
2. Environmentally sustainable agricultural production systems improved 
2.1  Rehabilitate irrigation systems and upgrade equipment at crop research institutes (Q2 2023). 
2.2  Set up inspection and testing facilities at the Institute of Plant Protection (Q1 2025). 
3. Technical, institutional, and management capacity and coordination strengthened 
3.1  Implement technical assistance (Q4 2020–Q1 2025). 
3.2  Assess capacity demands and prepare a detailed training program (Q2 2020–Q4 2024). 
3.3  Contract facilitation team (Q1 2021–Q1 2026). 
3.4  Form vegetable grower groups (Q3 2020). 
3.5  Set up winter greenhouses for diversification of vegetables, growing high-value crops (Q2 2021–Q3 2024). 
3.6  Train relevant aimag, soum, and bagh government officials (Q3 2020–Q1 2025). 
3.7  Establish and train CGGs on new technologies for farming, operation and maintenance of efficient 
irrigation systems, and business planning (Q3 2020–Q3 2023). 
Project Management Activities 
Establish PIU (Q2 2020). 
Appoint procurement agent (Q2 2020). 
Implement the environmental management plan and submit semiannual environmental monitoring reports 
to ADB from 2020 to 2025. 
Implement the gender action plan and the social development action plan from 2020 to 2025. 
Monitor and evaluate project impact, outcome, and outputs using the project performance management 
system; submit semiannual project progress reports from 2020 until 2025. 
Inputs 
ADB:      $40.00 million (loans) 
JFPR:      $2.00 million (grant) 
Government of Mongolia:  $4.25 million 
Assumptions for Partner Financing 
Not applicable 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, CGG = community grower group, ha = hectares, JFPR = Japan Fund for Poverty 
Reduction, PIU = project implementation unit, Q = quarter, RFI = results framework indicator. 
a  Government of Mongolia. 2016. Mongolia Sustainable Development Vision 2030. Ulaanbaatar. 
Contribution to ADB Results Framework: 
RFI A: Farmers using quality farm inputs and sustainable mechanization. Target 3,548 farmers. 
RFI B: Land with higher productivity. Target: 7,000 hectares.  
RFI C: Food safety and traceability standards improved. Target: 5,000 tests. 
Source: Asian Development Bank estimates.

metadata.Subject: The project will support the modernization of government-owned irrigation networks serving about 7,000 hectares (ha) of land. The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.
metadata.Title: Vegetable Production and Irrigated Agriculture: Report and Recommendation of the President
